cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
7, Boulevard de Ramleh, Alexandria, TELEPHONE No. 1,592.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Suez about April 5
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about April 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Orotava" will leave Port Said April 9
R.M.S. "Ophir" will leave Port Said April 22

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season 15th May - 15th September.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about April 11th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, will leave Port Said about April 14th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: COMPTOIR NATIONAL D'ESCOMPTE
div.p: DE PARIS.
CAPITAL: 150,000,000 frs,-£ 6,000,000 FULLY PAID UP. — HEAD OFFICE: 14, Rue Bergere, Paris
Alexandria Branch 11, Rue Cherif Pacha.—40 Branches in Paris, and 112 Throughout France.

Branches in London, Liverpool, Manchester, Morocco, Tunis, East India, Madagascar, Australia, etc. Bills Collected. Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. Stocks and Valuables received in safe custody. Purchase and Sale of Stock & Shares in Egypt and Abroad. Dividends Collected.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: Head Office : Athens — Capital 20,000.000 (Fully paid up). — Reserve 1,000,000.

Branches: London 55-58 Bishopsgate-street Within, Alexandria, Cairo, Constantinople, Smyrna, Candia, Canea, Piraeus
Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings
Bank Branch receives deposits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 80 to P.T. 20,000. 19-1-907

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

Siège Social au Caire, Succursale à Alexandria, Agence à Assiout, Assuoan, Benha, Beni-Suef, Chibin el Kom, Damanhour, Fayoum, Khartoum, Kéneh, Mansourah, Minieh, Port-Said, Suakin, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig, Mouski (Caire) et Londres (4 et 5, King William Street). La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

The IONIAN BANK LTD. transacts all ordinary banking business such as:

Advances on securities, merchandise, warrants, etc. Buying and selling of exchange on all principal centres abroad. Issue of drafts, letters of credits and telegraphic payments. div.p: CAIRO.
CAPITAL: Lstg. 600,000.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd
div.p: Weekly Mail Steamers from ALEXANDRIA to BRINDISI TIRESTE (VENICE), leave Saturdays at 4 p.m. having connection in Brindisi with the Express train on Tuesday morning to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London. Arrival at Trieste on Wednesday about 11 a.m. A Train de Luxe leaves the same evening, 6.35 p.m. for Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussels, Ostende and London. Arrival at London on Friday 5.12 p.m.
Weekly Intermediate Steamers from Alexandria to Trieste via Brindisi leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m.
Syria-Caramanian Line. Port Said, Jaffa, Beyrout, Tripoli, Alexandretta, Mersina, alternate Mondays: August 5, 19; Sept. 2, 16, 30; Oct. 14, 28; Nov. 11, 25; Dec. 9, 23: 4 p.m.
Syria-Cyprus Line. Beyrout, Limassol, Larnace, Mersina: alternate Tuesdays: Aug. 13, 27; Sept. 10, 24; Oct. 8, 22; Nov. 5, 19; Dec. 3, 17, 31, 4 p.m.
N.B.-During the present Quarantine in Syrian Ports against arrival from Egypt there is no connection between these lines and Alexandria on the outward voyage.
Far Eastern Lines. Sailing from Port Said: To Suez, Aden, Bombay, (accelerated Service) on or about Aug. 8; Sept. 7; Oct. 7, 22; Nov. 7, 22; Dec. 7, 22.
To Suez, Aden, Karachi, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon & Calcutta. Aug. 18; Sept. 18; Oct. 18; Nov. 18; Dec. 18.
To Suez, Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hongkong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobe, Sept. 3; Oct. 4; Nov. 3; Dec. 4; Jan. 3 (1908).
For information apply to the Agents: Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, Khartum, etc.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head: HOTEL BRISTOL. CAIRO.
div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.head: SAVOY HOTEL, Luxor (Upper Egypt)
div.p: NEW FIRST-CLASS HOTEL WITH EVERY MODERN COMFORT
SPLENDID SITUATION on the bank of the Nile, on the road to Karnak and within easy reach of Thrbes
Magnificent Views, Beautiful Surrondings, Garden, Spacious Terrace overlooking the River,
Bliliar Room, Smoking-Room, Reading-Room, Electric Light throughout.
Restaurant open to Non-Residents. Moderate Charges
Omnibus and Porter meet all Trains and Steamers.
HOTEL BEAU-RIVAGE, RAMLEH, OPENING IN MARCH
G. &M RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietors
Also Prop. of the BEAU-RIVAGE HOTEL, Ramleh Alexandria

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: "AL HAYAT" Helouan
div.p: First Class Health Resort
Unrivalled Position on the Mokattam Hills
96 metres above the level of the Nile, surrounded by desert.
All rooms full south with sheltered verandahs
Public Sitting Rooms in separate Pavilions communicating by glass corridors.
Electric Light–Steam-Heating–Lift.
Bathing, Air and Diet Cures. Resident Medical Director. All kinds of sports. Own stables. Omnibus meets all Trains.

MEAT DISHES, SOUPS, FISH, CHEESE, CURRIES, GAME, POULTRY & SALADS.
The Original & Genuine Worcestershire.
By Royal Warrant to H.M. THE KING.

div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - -.R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
WEDNESDAY, January 22, 1908.

div.head: "L'ALLEMAGNE CEST L'ENNEMI."
div.p: If any reliance could be placed upon the jeremiads of a French contemporary of Cairo our Teutonic brethren are a very perfidious people. They are for ever plotting to cause dissension between two of the Great Powers, England and Russia, the latter of which is France's staunch ally. Far worse than that, they are striving to put obstacles in the way of France's "peaceful penetration" into Morocco, which was her "quid pro quo" for renouncing her secular interests in Egypt. Through Germany's duplicity, France' will have to make new sacrifices to maintain the Algeciras compact. In Macedonia, England's policy is menaced by the Sultan of Turkey's bostihty to reforms. He has assumed an obdurate attitude which would never have been ventured upon but for Germany's covert support, In Persia, likewise, be is being used as a screen for German intrigue. All this would of course be very serious if it were true. But is it true? The answer to that question de-. pends upon testimony; and of testimony she has nothing but the "ipse dixit" of a writer, who builds his theories upon bare surmise. His "facts," or what he maker do duty for. such, are no doubt capable of frightening those who are susceptible to alarm and become easily prey to panic. But for 'men of firm mind and understanding" to employ legal phraseology, such warnings, based upon con jeotures which are purely imaginary, present no fear. On the contrary, they ask themselves why they are urged to believe all these dreadful things. Nations, unlike individuals, never practice knavery out of mere delight in taking advantage of & trusting neighbours. That sort of game in politics does not pay. In other words, honesty has been found, in the long run, to be the best policy. Why then should Germany, Machiavellian as our censor may deem her, adopt some other course 1 He can give no reason, nor anyone else. The real truth, though it pains us to give currency to it, is that certain French journalists, not the most reputable, think to obtain a cheap, popularity by goading at a foreign nation, which has proved itself superior to theirs, cot alone in that conflict, which is the crucial test of manliness, namely the field of battle, but in many departments of intellectual activity, whereof their nation formerly held the supremacy. It is not pleasant to take a back seat or to see oneself ousted by a rival. The practical mind, to be sure, accepts the lesson with due humility, studies the situation in all its bearings, and seeks by avoiding former errors to retrieve the past. But all, men are not endowed with sufficient common sense to take their vicissitudes philosophically Some are ever whining and repining at their ill-success, and casting the blame of their own shortcomings upon the shoulders of others, who they accuse of having adopted Unscrupulous methods to compass their discomfiture lu fact, to maligo '. competitor, whom has worsted you in lifos race affords to mean and superficial intelligen. does a modicum of consolation. We wish our French contemporary joy of his empire-shaking discoveries, which as far as positive proof goods are veritable mare's nests.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Facing the Sea on the New Quay of Alexandria
FIRST-CLASS HOTEL
Lately Built and Furnished.
TERMS P.T. 50 PER DAY,

div.head: Cholera Bulletin
div.p: The cholera bulletins of the 19th, 20th, and 22nd inst. report 744 deaths at Mecca and 34 deaths at Djeddah.

div.head: Helouan Casino
div.p: On the occasion of the dance to be held at Helouan Casino to-morrow a special train will run from Helowan to Cairo at 1.30 p.m.

div.head: The Brindiel Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P and 0.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at 4.80 o'clock to day:

div.head: British Recreation Club.
div.p: A small dance will take place at this Club on Saturday, 1st February, commencing at 9 p.m. prompt. Members are requested to apply for tickets, price P.T. 20, as early as possible.

div.head: Shepheard's and Ghezireh Palace.
div.p: Shepherd's annual grand ball with cotillon will be held on the 28th inst. and there will as usual, be a fancy dress hall at Ghezireh Palace Casino on Shrove Tuesday, the 3rd of March.

div.head: New Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: Tomorrow night the Door-Leblanc troupe will make their debut at the Alhambra theatre, The programme is well varied and the visit of this illusionist should attract large numbers to the theatre for the few nights that he will be in Alexandria.

div.head: The Calro Season.
div.p: The signs that the Cairo season is to be, after all, a successful one are daily made more evident. The bookings at Shepheard's and Ghezireh Palinee exceed considerably the management's anticipations, and, at the end of this month it is probable that Shepherds will have to refuse applications. Ghezireh Palace, too, is almost overfilled by the arrival of passengers by the "Cedric" the Heliopolis" and the "Caronia,' and in nearly all the hotels the bookings are heavy up to the end of March.

div.head: BEGGING IN CAIRO
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes :

The importunities of European beggars in the streets of Cairo are daily becoming more noticeable, and it is now almost impossible for aby one, more especially visitors, to walk the length of any of our principal streets with out being pestered by these men, who, unlike their pative companions in misfortune, invariably refuse to take no for an answer, and follow one up until the appearance of a policeman, or a refusal of more than ordinary curtness convince them that a retreat is advisable. A number of these men are cripples, and are therefore unable to work, but it is hardly fair to the public that the streets should be made hideous by the display of their infirmities and by the disgraceful manner in which they are allowed to whine for charity. Have the consulates of gugh people no interest in their welfare and no power to alleviate their sufferings except by allowing them to parade the streetski the manner described ? The native beggar 'is to be met with at every turn, but though he frequently bears the marks of visible suffering in a much more noticeable degree than the European, he is at least unobtrusive in his demand for alms, and it is the exception rather than the rule to be followed by one of these after having once refused to notice them. There are now a pumber of exceptionally persistent European boys about Cairo whom it is almost impossible to "shake of unless in possession of a fluent command of thě Arabic language, these boys some of them are little more than children-have every appearance of being well fed and are certainly well clothed, and it is ] astonishing that they should have-escaped the notice of the police for so long a time as they apparently have done. It is hardly likely that these well nourished youngsters are acting without direction, and it should not be difficult for the police to lay their bands upon those who are responsible for their presence in the streets. Some few of them wake a pretence of earning a livelihood by selling matches or other articles of that description, but this is only the usual shallow mask to the worst description of vagrancy with which the more expert of the professional beggars strive to cloak the real nature of their profession, and it is not fair that these lads should hold possession of the payments when there are so many more deserving people, who by reason of this competition are unable to earn the bare livelihood which wopla be otherwise open to them by this means. The public are undoubtedly to blaine in a great measure that this state of things has continued as "long as it has, if some of the residents of - Cairo would compare notes as to who were the least deserving of these street beggars and hand the more persistent of them over to the nearest policeman, they would be doing the whole city a service by ridding them of what bids fit to become a nuisance such as hitherto has only been met with at the church entrances of the Continent.

div.head: THE NATIONALIST PARTY
div.p: Strennous efforts are now being made by Mustapha Pasha Kamel to capture some Irish Nationalist M.P.'s to represent his party in the House of Commons. The recent visit to Cairo of Dr. Rutherford, M P., was a cruel blow to the followers of Kamel, who fully expected that that earnest Radical would allow himself to be patronised by them. But their hopes of: being able to make use of Dr. Rutherford in the House of Commons were cruelly shattered, for that gentleman clearly showed that all his sympathies were with the Constitutional ReEuro League. The Party of Sheikh Aly Youssef won a great victory by inducing Dr Rutber. ford to attend the historic banquet at the Savoy Hotel. The chagrin of the Nationalist Party is extreme. If they do succeed in getting one or two Irish Home Rulere to back them in the House of Commons, we shall be treated to Live-interesting spectacle of two Egyptian parties, each bitterly hostile to the other, forming, as it were, a microonsin of Nationalist politics in Egypt, waging their warfare within the walls of the British Parliament.

div.head: PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
div.p: The terrific internecine struggles among the members of the Party of the People have resulted in a serious secession for it is said that a considerable following have gone over to the Party of Constitutional Reformers. There still remain, however, a number of stalwarts, who refuse to desert the programme of the late Sheikh M bam-d Abdou and they are determined to carry on their campaign with unremitting energy. Whether this party will ever obtain a bold on Egyptian public opinion is very doubtful The Patty was favoured by Lord Cromer, as is seen by his last Report. It consequently received a great deal of support from the ranks of the higher native officials and at one time seemed to be a power in the land. But as soon as Lord Crmer departed the Party of the People entirely changed its programme. With an utter disregard for political consistency it determined to angle for the support of the populace by attacking LordCromer and the occupation with acrimonious virulence, although up to that time it had been criticised by the Nationaliste for conceiving its orders direct from the British Agency. What precisely was the meaning of this chameleon-like attitude is hard to discover unless it be to make a bid for popularity superior to that of Kainel. It over the Party Wishes to attain to a position of respect in the eyes of any but young Nation slist politicians, this policy of tergiversation will have to be renounced once and for all.

div.head: THE REFORM PARTY.
div.p: The Party of Constitutional Reform is actively engaged in organising its new political headquarters opposite the Turf Club. Their club house is very comfortable and nicely furnished in the European style without any Oriental garishness. The furniture is good and substantial and the sanitary arrangements are excellent. Here may be seen disporting themselves nightly not only the protagonists of Constitutional Reform but also their new friends, the secessionists from the camp of the Sheikh Abdou Party, whọ bask in cushioned ease and familiarity with their former antagonista.

div.head: THE REPUBLICAN PARTY.
div.p: Not much activity is observable among those Egyptians, who are in favour of Egypt being in mediately declared an independent and autonomous Republic. It is said that they are busily engaged in preparing their programme and drawing up an elaborate series of statutes. The Republicans are also endeavouring surreptitiously. pusly to obtain converts to their creed from all the other parties. It is rumoured that Mustapha Pasha Kamel fears these persons more than any other of his opponents, it was well known that for years his ambition has been to be the first President of the New Republic of Egypt, which only under his guidance would stand a chance of becoming the compeer of Japan as a renascent Oriental state.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIBERAL PARTY.
div.p: Much comment has been aroused by the silence of Mohamed Bey Wahid, the leader of the Egyptian. Liberal Party. It was fully expected that the chief of the Liberals would have embraced the opportunity of Dr. Rutberford's visit to send that gentleman a lengthy telegram, but as no such telegram has appeared in the columns of the "Progrès" or "Al Mokactam," it is considered that he must be vexed because that M.P. did not visit him when he made a trip to Helonan when he was in Cairo Dr. Rutherford when at Helonan attended the races there instead of paying homage to the Bey. As it was the first time in his life that Dr. Rutherford had ever seen a horse race; it must be concluded that this Unexpected spectacle was so absorbing that he forgot the other and more serious calls upon his time there.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Westcott liner "Joshua Nicholson" sailed from Malta this morning and is due here with general cargo next Sunday morning.
